Name: Dr Rosena Allin-Khan
Message: My very first week as a doctor was the week of the 7/7 bombings. I know from day one what terror attacks do to the emergency services. An incredible amount of work goes into preparing for multiple casualties. And the emergency services themselves can be very nervous. It’s a very daunting time. But without fail, our emergency services step up. It was no different during the London Bridge attack. The police officers who answered - within minutes - the first call had no idea what they were going into. It is times like that we really do see the best of our services. We must never take for granted the sacrifices they make. Each time there is a terror attack or a tragedy like Grenfell, we see our emergency services doing us proud. We see off-duty medics, police, firefighters coming in to help their teams. And that’s to save as many lives as possible. I worked with Dr Martin Griffiths when I was at the Royal London and he’s a great example of this. Martin was off duty when the London...
Link Text: Emergency services do the nation proud, says Dr Rosena Allin-Khan

Name: Richard Burgon MP
Message: The decision to finally grant a panel in the Grenfell Inquiry is a step forward and a result of the tenacious campaigning by survivors and bereaved family members But lots of questions remain unanswered. For example, why is the panel only going to sit in Phase 2 of the Inquiry? Where are we with the second demand in the public petition about survivors' lawyers having all the evidence from the start and being able to cross-examine the witnesses, as happened in the Lawrence Inquiry? What mechanisms are there to guarantee the ongoing confidence of survivors and bereaved family members in the Inquiry? For the Grenfell Inquiry to deliver truth and justice, it must always have the full confidence of the bereaved families and survivors. At tomorrow’s Grenfell Inquiry parliamentary debate we need greater clarity from the Government, not the delays and obfuscations we have had over recent months.

Name: Tom Watson
Message: Footballers and football clubs often get a bad press. But what Les Ferdinand and QPR have contributed to the local community in the aftermath of Grenfell deserves real praise. It started in the immediacy of the tragedy with Loftus Road becoming a centre for food, blankets and donations; then came Game4Grenfell - the charity match that raised half a million pounds. Now there's on-going football training for the children, psychological support for survivors and a long-term pledge to support the community. Reflecting on the 152 families still without housing, Les, who grew up on the estate, says: "It’s ridiculous to think that these people who lost loved ones, lost friends, are still holed up in hotels. “People do a lot of talking about what’s right and what’s wrong but it’s the actions that count. And we’ve not done enough.” We can never do enough. But Les, you and your club are doing the right thing. Thank you.

Name: Bridget Phillipson
Message: I know this has been a really difficult year for many in our community. Brexit is still causing division and uncertainty, there are growing pressures on public services, and it’s becoming increasingly common to see people sleeping rough in our city centres again. Six months ago we were horrified by the appalling loss of life at Grenfell Tower and there have been several devastating terrorist attacks across the UK. It is easy to feel despondent and powerless when so much seems wrong in the world, but I want to take this opportunity to thank some of the people who are making a real difference to our lives every day. So here's to all the NHS staff who are working shifts to care for those in need, the extraordinarily brave police officers and firefighters who run towards danger to keep us safe time and time again, and those in the intelligence services, who have helped to foil more terror plots than we'll ever know about. I am calling on the Government to provide grant funding to all councils that require it.

Name: Clive Lewis MP
Message: Eid Mubarak to all those celebrating Eid-al-Adha in Norwich South and across the world!
Link Text: Jeremy Corbyn
Description:
I would like to wish Muslims in Britain and across the world Eid Mubarak.

During Hajj, the Muslim pilgrimage, Muslims from all over the world to come together to pray for humanity, to reflect on themselves and to commemorate the Prophet Ibrahim.

Today, Muslims remember this story by carrying its message with them. A message of compassion for those less fortunate and of sharing what we have with others.

These values are more relevant today than ever. We must come together in our communities and as a society to draw strength from our shared humanity.

This year, I have travelled across the country and visited many mosques. I have seen the work Muslims are doing in their communities; volunteering in foodbanks and community centers, and supporting the families of Grenfell Tower. That is the true spirit of Eid.

From myself, and on behalf of the Labour Party, I wish you Eid Mubarak.

Message: This weekend over a million people will attend Notting Hill Carnival, one of Britain's most iconic events. Carnival emerged as a response to bigotry and hatred faced by black communities. It united people through art, music and dance in celebration of Caribbean culture, black history and our diverse and multicultural society. This year's Carnival comes as we mourn the tragedy of the Grenfell Tower fire. This important event aims to help the local community to heal, as the very first Carnival did in the 1960s. Carnival-goers will not only celebrate Carnival, but also reflect on inequality and injustice in our society and resolve to work together to overcome them. The Carnival is beautifully captured in Benjamin Zephaniah's poem, Carnival Days: On days like these we dance to us, With the drum beat of liberation Under the close cover of European skies, We dance like true survivors We dance to the sounds of our dreams. ... Name: Nic Dakin
Message: My Diary for the week ending June 18th. The absolute horror of the Grenfell Tower fire make any words empty and inadequate. I could hardly watch the devastating scenes from the catastrophe. So much pain and suffering. A manmade, seemingly preventable disaster in 21st century Britain at the heart of one of London’s richest boroughs. The agonising grief of a community let down and the amazing heroism of emergency services personnel contrasted with the flatfooted response of national and local Government. Of course everyone living in tower blocks all over the country will be anxious about their own safety now and understandably so. I was reassured to be contacted by Ongo who have the Crosby and Trent View House Flats to be told they were tacking immediate steps to reassure tenants. One of my priorities this week is to double check this. We seem to be in a time of awful events coming from nowhere with yet another suspected terrorist attack reported this morning. Name: Jon Trickett
Message: Following the tragic fire at Grenfell Tower in London, there is an understandable level of anxiety and concern surrounding the safety of multi-storey tower blocks. Today I received a letter from Kevin Dodd, the Chief Executive of Wakefield and District Housing (WDH) assuring the safety of residents in WDH multi-storey blocks. Mr Dodd firstly reassured me that WDH use a completely different kind of cladding from the type used at Grenfell Tower in London. The cladding used by WDH has a fully compliant fire retardant rating from the manufacturer. He also gave assurances that all WDH flats comply with all fire safety requirements, and are inspected every three months by West Yorkshire Fire and Rescue Service. I have been told that there is a rigorous inspection regime currently in place to make sure all the accesses are clear at all times and each flat has a hard wired smoke and heat detector. Name: Dan Jarvis
Message: My thoughts today are with all those affected by the devastating fire at Grenfell Tower in West London. My heartfelt condolences go to those who have lost family and friends and particularly to those still waiting to hear whether their loved ones are safe. As a father and husband I can hardly bear to think about some of the decisions that people had to make and the heartache many must now be feeling. So many more lives would have been lost had it not been for the professionalism and bravery of our firefighters. Our emergency services have once again done our country proud. There seems to be no end to the horrific circumstances we ask them to face or the courage they show. But now we need to ask how preventable this one was. It goes without saying that all those affected deserve a number of answers. Message: READ & SHARE: I have been contacted by several concerned constituents, following the tragedy at the Grenfell Tower in Kensington. I am grateful for the prompt response from Ian Davis and for his statement on the issue which I provide below: “A letter is being prepared which will go out to all residents in tower blocks this week. However we can assure you that all 52 tower blocks in the borough received a full fire risk assessment in 16/17 and will do so again this year. An additional round of inspections specifically focusing on fire risk will take place on Thursday [15th June] and Friday [16th June]. Name: Lucy Powell MP
Message: For the many residents living in former council tower blocks, particularly in Hulme, Ancoats, Miles Platting and Newton Heath, I have contacted both the Council and local housing associations to ask for full fire assessments and for urgent communication with residents. The Chief Executive and Deputy Leader (responsible for housing) are taking this matter extremely seriously and will update me and residents as their investigations continue. I have also asked for robust discussions with developers, managing agents and free-holders of the many privately-owned towers blocks in city centre, Ancoats and elsewhere, to ensure these blocks meet the highest possible fire standards. Again, I will update residents as I get more news. Undoubtedly there will be many lessons to be learned from the Grenfell Tower disaster. I have long argued for tighter regulation and oversight in this area, particularly, in Manchester, for privately-owned blocks which continue to be built at a fast rate in our city.
